seo.title: Turbidity Explained: Water Clarity Measurement
seo.description: Understanding turbidity: what causes cloudiness in water, how to measure clarity, and what changes in turbidity indicate.

sections.html:
Zone 2 • Measurement

Turbidity & Clarity

Measuring Light Scatter — What's Suspended in Water

Turbidity measures how much light is scattered by suspended particles. Clear water = low turbidity.

What Causes Turbidity

  • Suspended particles — sediment, algae, organic matter
  • Colloidal particles — minerals, clays
  • Precipitates — minerals coming out of solution
  • Air bubbles — temporary, from agitation

Measuring Turbidity

Lab Methods

  • Nephelometer (NTU units)
  • Light transmission meters

DIY Methods

  • Secchi disk (depth visibility)
  • Comparison tubes
  • Photography with backlight
DIY Tests

Interpreting Changes

  • Clearing over time — particles settling out
  • Increasing cloudiness — precipitation, contamination
  • Stable clarity — dissolved (ionic) content, not suspended

Track turbidity at multiple time points: T0, T30, T2h, T24h.

items.question: Is cloudy water bad?
items.answer: Not necessarily. It depends on what's causing the cloudiness. Mineral precipitates are different from contamination.

items.question: Why does Andara water look different?
items.answer: Mineral content affects appearance. Ionic solutions are clear; colloidal/suspended particles create turbidity.
